Award.AwardTitle: The Archaeology of Herring: Reconstructing the Past to Redeem the Future
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) is a cultural keystone species for many Alaska Natives, and is a critical resource in the marine food web for much of coastal Alaska. The appearance of herring in the spring signals the start of the seasonal round after a long winter. Herring is a key dietary resource during this time, but to some, herring is an economic mainstay throughout the year. Alaska Natives, as well as a range of North Pacific species, depend on abundant and geographically widespread populations of herring. In 1989, the Exxon Valdez oil spill devastated Prince William Sound herring populations in the northern Gulf of Alaska (Thorne and Thomas2008). The southern Gulf of Alaska has been impacted by commercial fishing, habitat degradation, and environmental changes over the past century. Bering Sea communities also depend on herring; in the words of Nelson Islander Louise Kanrilak, ?herring are very important to us. When we are out of herring, we are out of food? (Barker 1993:73). The scientific debate over the status of herring has been complicated by the lucrative commercial sac roe fishery that supplies herring eggs for Asian markets. Local and Traditional Knowledge bearers have witnessed the decline of herring (Thornton et al. 2010a) and many argue that herring are being managed in a depleted state. Alaska Native subsistence fishers and egg-collectors are sounding the alarm, while biologists debate whether herring populations are ?endangered,? ?threatened? or ?struggling? (Carls et al. 2009). Herring have already abandoned some spawning locations (ADFG 2011), and several First Nations in British Columbia have been forced to stop harvesting herring and spawn altogether (Speller et al. 2010).

This project aims to demonstrate how zooarchaeological and paleo-genetic research can be used to understand the dynamics of ancient fishing and fisheries and produce new knowledge that can advance resource conservation today. It will support the development and refinement of new methods of recovering and studying ancient DNA, and will greatly expand knowledge of the long-term history of Alaska Native use of herring. By encompassing the entire range of Pacific herring across Alaska, it will complement current efforts in British Columbia and integrate the knowledge of social scientists, biologists, and Local and Traditional Knowledge bearers. The health of herring is essential to the entire North Pacific marine ecosystem. Archaeological assemblages from across coastal Alaska constitute an unmatched archive of environmental data. This project aims to develop a more complete understanding of the ancient Alaska Native use of herring to better assess the historical abundance, biogeography, and genetic diversity of herring in the past. This effort aims to improve herring fisheries management to benefit a wide range of stakeholders in the Arctic, subarctic, and beyond. The project will gather samples of herring bones from archaeological sites across coastal Alaska for ancient DNA analysis. Preliminary work has shown that ancient mitochondrial DNA can be extracted from herring bones and is well-preserved. Yang and colleagues are working to extract nuclear DNA, which will facilitate comparisons to genetic results emerging from the study of the DNA of extant herring. In this project, ancient DNA from 150 herring bone samples will be studied to establish phylogenetic and geographic relationships. The age of many of these samples is established, but radiocarbon dates will be obtained for those samples lacking dates.

Understanding the temporal context will allow the researchers to identify changes over time. Collaborations between archaeologists, Native communities, biologists, and managers working in BritishColumbia and Washington State will permit region-wide understanding of the ancient use of herring across the North Pacific. The results of the genetic study will be disseminated to six communities in coastal Alaska through a traveling workshop which will leave behind resource materials that can be exhibited and will stimulate further study and engagement in management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Archaeology of Herring: Reconstructing the Past to Redeem the Future

M. Moss, July 30, 2018

What are the major goals of the project?

The project aims to develop a more complete understanding of the ancient Alaska Native use of Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) to better assess the historical abundance, biogeography, and genetic diversity of herring in the past. The effort aims to improve herring fisheries management to benefit a wide range of stakeholders in the Arctic, Subarctic, and beyond.

What we have demonstrated so far is that DNA can be recovered from archaeological herring around the northeast Pacific as far back as there is an archaeological record of them. The oldest herring bones thus far tested date to more than 10,500 cal BP. The interim results have been published (Moss et al. 2016). We retain confidence of the potential to expand the analyses and develop a richer pattern of biological variability.  The resulting data show genetic continuity between archaeological and modern herring populations.  At this point, we have expanded beyond what was reported by Speller et al. (2012), having tripled the earlier archaeological dataset and confirmed the overall genetic patterns. 

We have learned that mitochondrial DNA is not sufficient for distinguishing ancient herring.  Over the last 32 months, we have been working with Hauser and Petrou on the DNA of modern herring in an attempt to get the information needed for Yang, Speller, and Rodrigues to be able to genotype the ancient fish represented in the archaeological samples. It is taking longer than anticipated because 1) the herring haven't returned in the numbers Alaska Department of Fish & Game projected, and 2) issues of contamination require new techniques of de-contamination. The number of herring harvested in Sitka in the spring of 2018 was only 26% of what was projected by ADFG. Yet even with the limitations regarding sampling modern herring, Petrou and Hauser have found five genetic markers in modern herring that Yang and Speller can target in the ancient samples. Speller has extracted samples from some ancient Puget Sound herring and at the Center for GeoGenetics University of Copenhagen, shotgun sequencing was used. The DNA preservation was exceptional, showing high potential for hybridization capture in the future. Petrou has worked with Speller at the University of York this year (2018) and they have made additional technical progress. I have rounded up additional archaeological samples (Tebenkof Bay), but we need additional analyses to be completed before proceeding to test the ancient samples.

We still plan to analyze ~70 more archaeological samples, even though my collaborators have yet to develop the specific assays.  The amount of time needed to actually conduct the technical work is still indeterminate, but we are hopeful it can begin by August 31, 2019.  We are clearing technological hurdles, but additional ones likely await us and we might have to apply for another extension next year.

In order to understand the relative abundance of different herring populations in ancient times, Hauser and Petrou are have created a genetic baseline of contemporary herring populations using RAD (Restriction site Associated) DNA sequencing. They have synthesized this baseline information, and then designed assays for nuclear DNA that can be used to genotype ancient samples and assign ancient fish back to their population of origin.  This grant has supported genomic sequencing of samples from B.C. and Washington, as well as Alaska. Ultimately, we hope this technique can then be used to distinguish Sitka, Hoonah Channel, and Haida Gwaii herring.

What is the impact on other disciplines?

Ultimately, we hope that local communities can use this knowledge to consider alternatives to current fisheries management policies. We also hope that fisheries scientists responsible for management will benefit from the longer term perspective on the resources they manage that only zooarchaeology can provide.  While this research focuses on a single species, because Pacific herring is the lynchpin of ocean food webs, it affects a wide range of other animal species.  Study of herring and wise management of herring populations are essential for insuring the health of many other marine organisms, including fish, birds, and marine mammals.  All of these are animals upon which Alaska Natives have relied for thousands of years.
